instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 450mA
threads.message: Hello, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 machine here with 5V and taking .450mA. This board has a ton of corrosion everywhere, some of which I have cleaned up. I have replaced the <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>. Currently, <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> gets warm, but not burning. It sits at 40C under thermal cam. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL> both measure at 8.2V I know this isn't correct, but I am unsure HOW they have the same voltage values. The same behavior is exhibited in the enclosure. Corrosion hit the backlight circuit area, as well as left speaker area and keyboard and trackpad connector area. No liquid was found on or near <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>. Im a little lost on where to go from here. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is 250 ohms to ground. diode mode is 0.145 when it should be around .500.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 450mA
threads.message:
With 8.2V at <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> M1 CPU is fried; don't waste more time with it.
Because of corrosion, (at least) one of <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>/20/40 got burnt and shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>.
